Somebody extrapolates one science teacher at a charter to all teaching situations has no business criticizing how we do our jobs!

I'm wondering where "over 100 days/year to prepare lesson plans" comes from?
Are you suggesting this work be done during an educator's non-contract time? Most teachers use this time to either work another job, or to take additional coursework to further their education. In addition, most I know also "donate" their time to work on curriculum development. Before leaving the business world to pursue work in education, I too used to believe the myth of summers off for teachers. This couldn't be farther from the truth. At least here in Silicon Valley, teachers can not afford not to hold two jobs. Summer provides some additional time to try and make some more money to support their career as an educator. Perhaps if teachers were paid a living wage (paid for the whole year of work we are already doing for free) then there wouldn't be a problem.
This professional does not compress her worklife into 9 months. And she has to take her vacations along with all the other families who abide by the school calendar.

Video tapes of lectures and discussions?  Who does this videoing while the educator is teaching?  Who pays for video equipment for each classroom?  I do believe there would be legal issues of posting students in a classroom discussing issues.  When it became possible to do so, I put all my PowerPoint lectures/explanations on line as well as any handouts and homework assignments.  You would be amazed at how few students availed themselves of this valuable information, and I taught in an upper-middle class private school.  My experience over 40 years of high school teaching is that parents who devalue what I did in the classroom enough to remove their children for vacations have children who devalue school too much to avail themselves of what I supplied on line.  The apple doesn't fall far from the tree.  My colleagues and I usually worked much harder than many of our students.

Some parents work in partnerships such as medical practices where vacation time is rigidly controlled and doesn't necessarily follow the school calendar. Military families and 2 earner families also have challenges working vacations into a school calendar.
With regards to the ' extra burden ' placed upon teachers, such a burden should not exist in the first place.
Teachers have over 100 days/year to prepare lesson plans. The internet; voice recognition, scanning software, cameras, desktop publishing, etc. are cheap/open source and available to all.
Any teacher should be able to make the entirety of their course content available on-line for students and parents. That would be lecture notes, source material, worksheets, videotape of lectures and discussions. This material should be available for the entire semester from the start of the school year.
One math teacher in our charter school does this and I'm willing to bet that succeeding years only require her to make limited revisions.
If a child has a question about the material, asking the teacher in advance is no more of a burden then asking in 'real time.'
A profession that compresses their worklife into 9 months of the year has little standing to be offering criticism of how the rest of us balance schooling and family life,

Actually a route from most of the contiguous United States through Alaska is not as absurd as it sounds (my Geography major coming through here) for points in Far East Asia (Japan, Korea, North East and Eastern China - and probably all of settled China).

Why? Because the shortest route between East Asia and the U.S., be it Seattle or New York is what's called "A Great Circle Route."

On a flat map, the shortest route appears to be straight lines east or west. But the Earth is a sphere. On a Sphere, the shortest routes over long distances are great circle routes.

I've traveled to Europe and Korea/Japan a lot. From Europe you come back over Greenland, of all places. To East Asia you fly over Alaska. These are great ciricle routes. (When going the opposite direction, flights follow more of a straight line route, in part because of the jet stream, which blows at about 300mph from west to east over the oceans at mid latitudes and very high altitudes: despite taking a longer route, the time in the air is usually an hour less because of the greater speed).

So a train route through Alaska is not as silly as it seems. In my mind, there is no way a high speed magleve train could be as fast as a plane flying at over 500 miles an hour over the most direct course possible. But if we factor in affects on the environment we might change our minds. Jets consume and burn a lot of fossil fuels and leave giant contrails up in the atmosphere affecting the climate below. So maybe...

It seems highly unlikely that any of the approximately 310,000 California natives present when Fr. Serra arrived in 1769 remained 100 years later. Of the (presumably) 50,000 or so present in 1869, most were probably born after Spanish rule ended in 1821. What the Spanish did in California was ghastly, especially when evaluated by today's aspirational standards. The fact that it was the usual way European colonists treated indigenes at the time doesn't mitigate that. Perhaps the Franciscans and other orders could have refused to participate in the subjugation of California. How a more secular occupation would have treated the natives is an open question. Junipero Serra died after only 15 years in California. I have no dog in the fight over whether he should be canonized, but burdening him with all the sins committed against the natives for a subsequent 85 years by the Spanish, the Mexicans, and so on through the first generation of California's U.S. statehood seems a bit excessive.

Thank you, Gail Collins, for stating the obvious. There is no greater indication that our national politics has descended into Kafka-esque, "Alice in Wonderland" absurdity than the fact that raising the federal gas tax from its anachronistically low current level is such a taboo.

Our transportation infrastructure is falling apart, and the cowards in Washington are scrambling to find ways to make the other guy pay just so the American people don't have to be told there's no such thing as a free lunch--that there's no such thing as a functioning capitalist economy without transportation investment by government.

Gas prices are going to go up one way or another from their current artificial lows. The question is whether that increase is going to be pocketed by the Saudis and ExxonMobil or it's going to be plowed back into rebuilding our nation's crumbling infrastructure and maybe, just maybe making our nation a little less dependent on dwindling oil supplies.

Gail, just one complaint. When it comes to compromising on mass transit to get a gas tax passed, let's at least start by not making the compromise be the opening bid. There's no better way to fight our oil addiction or vehicles' contribution to climate change than mass transit.

And I must correct myself. When it comes to "cowards in Congress," in all fairness the only cowards are the Democrats. Sadly, the Republicans can gleefully fight a gas-tax increase knowing full well that doing so is in their political interest.
